fields.description:
h3. Environment:

* Fisheye 4.8.0 windows installer
* Windows 10
* AdoptOpenJDK version jdk8u232-b09 hotspot 
(OpenJDK8U-jdk_x64_windows_hotspot_8u232b09.msi)

h3. Steps to reproduce:
* Install AdoptOpenJDK
* Install Fisheye, create user account
* Log into Fisheye using this user

h3. Result
 * avatar in top menu does not render
 * all graphics (e.g. repository charts) do not render
 * exception in the log file:

{noformat}
2019-10-29 02:00:00,251 WARN  [main ] fisheye Run-setLibraryProperties - Problem initing graphics environment, images may not render2019-10-29 02:00:00,251 
WARN  [main ] fisheye Run-setLibraryProperties - Problem initing graphics environment, images may not renderjava.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: Could not initialize class java.awt.Toolkit
 at com.cenqua.fisheye.ctl.Run.setLibraryProperties(Run.java:421) [fisheye.jar:?]
 at com.cenqua.fisheye.ctl.BaseCommand.handleCommonArguments(BaseCommand.java:166) [fisheye.jar:?]
 at com.cenqua.fisheye.ctl.Run.mainImpl(Run.java:74) [fisheye.jar:?]
 at com.cenqua.fisheye.ctl.Run.main(Run.java:55) [fisheye.jar:?]
 at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) [?:1.8.0_232]
 at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62) [?:1.8.0_232]
 at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43) [?:1.8.0_232] at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:498) [?:1.8.0_232]
 at com.cenqua.fisheye.FishEyeCtl.mainImpl(FishEyeCtl.java:101) [fisheyeboot.jar:?]
 at com.cenqua.fisheye.FishEyeCtl.main(FishEyeCtl.java:44) [fisheyeboot.jar:?]
{noformat}

h3. Notes
 * this does not happen when Oracle JDK is used (tested on jdk8u202)
 * this does not happen on AdoptOpenJDK update 202 (OpenJDK8U-jdk_x64_windows_hotspot_8u202b08)

h3. Workaround

Install Adopt OpenJDK in a different version than 8u232
fields.summary: 'Could not initialize class java.awt.Toolkit' on Adopt OpenJDK 8u232

fields.description:
According to [https://www.postgresql.org/support/versioning/] page PostgreSQL 9.5 will become end-of-life on February, 2021.

Deprecate PostgreSQL 9.5 in Fisheye/Crucible 4.8 (EOL ~ Dec, 2021).

End support for PostgreSQL 9.5 in Fisheye/Crucible 4.9 (EOL ~ May, 2022).
fields.summary: Deprecate PostgreSQL 9.5

fields.description:
According to https://www.perforce.com/maintenance-support#tab-panel-26751
standard support for Perforce 2017.x ends 24 Oct 2019 and extended on 24 Oct 2021

Announce Fisheye/Crucible 4.8 the last release supporting Perforce 2017.x and older:

https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/supported-platforms-960155252.html
fields.summary: Deprecate Perforce 2017.x and older

fields.description:
When a commit has multiple parents, all of these parents are sent through the REST API when the Jira development panel requests them. Multiple parents flag a merge commit in that development panel. However, there is a case where a commit exists in multiple branches, so it has multiple parents. Though this would not be a merge commit, anything relying on multiple parents signifying a merge would have incorrect information.

Either only one parent should be sent in these situations, or a flag should be sent along with the commits indicating this is not a merge. The Jira development panel would then need to honor this flag.

https://getsupport.atlassian.com/browse/PS-46999
fields.summary: Flag multi-branch commits in the REST API

fields.description:
According to http://www.oracle.com/us/support/library/lifetime-support-technology-069183.pdf:

* Premier support ended 31 Jul 2018
* Extended support ends 31 Jul 2021

End support for Oracle 12c R1 in Fisheye and Crucible.
fields.summary: End support for Oracle 12c R1

fields.description:
According to this page https://www.mysql.com/support/supportedplatforms/database.html MySQL 8 is supported on all major operating systems and MySQL 5.6 and 5.7 are no longer supported on some versions (e.g. RedHat Enterprise Linux 8, Windows 2019 Server).

Add support for MySQL 8 in Fisheye and Crucible.
fields.summary: Support MySQL 8

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When using SSH key authentication, the key is rejected if the incorrect SSH key format is used.
h3. Example Steps to Reproduce
 # Create an RSA SSH Key Pair using {{ssh-keygen}}
{noformat}
ssh-keygen -t rsa
{noformat}

 # Add the Public Key to your Fisheye repository using "Upload private key for ssh"

h3. Expected Results

The SSH key to be a valid key.
h3. Actual Results

Uploading the key the following error is displayed:
 * The file you uploaded is not a valid private key

h3. Notes

This occurs when the version of OpenSSH has {{RFC4716}} as the default key format.
h3. Workaround

Create the key using PEM format, which {{RFC4716}} replaced. For example:
{noformat}
ssh-keygen -m PEM -t rsa
{noformat}
fields.summary: SSH Key rejected when RFC4716 format Keys used

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Upon SVN repository being added as a new repository in Fisheye, the *Test Connection* button action results in _Connection succeeded_ although the username and password are not being added. This suspected as the *Test Connection* is using the cache of an existing repository credential to authentication connection to SVN Server. However, upon restarting FeCru instance, the newly added repositories are running into authentication error and require a manual restart repository to fix.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# [SVN repository setup|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/subversion-960155467.html#Subversion-SVNrepositorysetup] to add an SVN repository with username and password. Complete the steps/process.
#  Followed by adding another SVN repository without username and password. Test the connection.

h3. Actual Results
The connection test is successful.

h3. Expected Results
The connection test should be failed to indicate the absence of authentication credential.

h3. Workaround
Required, if there is no workaround please state:
Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: SVN repository authentication cache cause misleading configuration for new repository authentication

fields.description: The Atlassian Troubleshooting and Support Tools (ATST) plugin prior to version 1.17.2 which was used in Fisheye & Crucible before  version 4.7.2, allows an unprivileged user to initiate periodic log scans and send the results to a user-specified email address due to a missing authorization check. The email message may contain configuration information about the application that the plugin is installed into.
fields.summary: Improper Authorization in Fisheye & Crucible through ATST Plugin - CVE-2019-15005

It may be worth still logging the full exception if debug logging is enabled because it's not inconceivable this information might be useful when diagnosing an issue. (right now the full stack trace as above is printed regardless of if debug logging is enabled)
  
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Fisheye throws IO exceptions on network interruption

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of September 2019|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#B2D4FF | titleBGColor=#B2D4FF | bgColor=#EAF1FC}
Microsoft has not released any major updates for IE11 since 2015, and has [recently discouraged the use of IE11 as a default browser|https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/Windows-IT-Pro-Blog/The-perils-of-using-Internet-Explorer-as-your-default-browser/ba-p/331732]. 

To allow us to continue to take advantage of modern web standards to deliver improved functionality and the best possible user experience across all of our products, we have decided to end support for IE11. *Fisheye 4.8 will be the last IE11-supported version.*

End of support means we will not fix bugs that are specific to IE11, and will begin to introduce features that aren't compatible with this browser. 

Find out more about this change from our [announcement|https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Feedback-Forum-articles/Retiring-IE11-support-for-Atlassian-cloud-server-and-data-center/ba-p/1185312].

If you have questions or concerns about this change, please comment on this issue.

{panel}
fields.summary: Deprecate support for IE11

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Avatars might not be displayed correctly if compatible Gravatar server is not respecting the size parameter precisely and instead is returning an image of the closest size that it already has.
h3. Environment
Any environment.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
Use external gravatar server as the avatar source with a too large avatar to display. 

h3. Expected Results
Fecru resizes the avatar and displays it correctly nonetheless the received size.
h3. Actual Results
Fecru doesn't display the avatars that are too big.

No exception is visible in the logs.
h3. Notes

(Optional - If Necessary)
h3. Workaround

Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available.

fields.description:
Currently Fisheye & Crucible use a Flash applet (ZeroClipboard-1.2.1.swf) to provide copy to clipboard functionality (checkout URL, snippet page, selection history).

Since most browsers support this directly from JavaScript via "execCommand" method:

https://www.w3schools.com/jsref/met_document_execcommand.asp
https://www.w3schools.com/howto/howto_js_copy_clipboard.asp

let's remove existing Flash applet and replace it with JavaScript.
fields.summary: Use JavaScript instead of Flash for copying to clipboard

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Nowadays, the [{{GET /rest-service-fecru/admin/users/\{name\}}}|https://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/latest/wadl/fecru.html#rest-service-fecru:admin:users:name] REST API endpoint does not retrieve the user creation date, and that information might be useful for our customers.

h3. Suggested Solution
Include the user creation date to the response. This information is stored at database level, in the {{CWD_USER.CREATED_DATE}} column.

h3. Workaround
There are no known workarounds yet for retrieving that information via REST API.
fields.summary: REST API for obtaining user details should retrieve the date the user was created

fields.description:
h3. Problem

In Fisheye and Crucible there is the following link available:

'Administration' > 'Application links' > '...' > 'JIRA settings'

In versions prior to 4.6.0 it presented the following screen:

 !fisheye-update-jira-server.png|thumbnail! 

which did not allow to perform any actions. 

In version 4.6.0 and higher, clicking on the link displays an error page:

!fisheye-update-jira-server-error.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Note

This is a left-over of very old functionality, which allowed to add Jira servers and setup sub-tasks, see old YT video from 2012: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JG6E1p9csMY All this functionality has been replaced by the 'Application links' plugin.


h3. Suggested solution

Remove the 'JIRA settings' link from the '...' drop-down. 

OR

Provide a blank page which will inform user to open 'Configure Fisheye server' link on the Jira side.

Jira > 'Administration' > 'Applications' > 'Application links' > '...' > 'Configure FishEye Server' redirects to:

Jira > 'Administration' > 'Applications' > 'Fisheye'

 !fisheye-crucible-configuration.png|thumbnail! 

Document also that it's possible to set up project links:

Fisheye > 'Administration' > 'Projects' > '...' > 'Application links' > 'Add link' > 'Jira' 

We may also add links to documentation, e.g.:

https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/linking-fisheye-to-jira-960155618.html
https://confluence.atlassian.com/crucible/linking-crucible-to-jira-394464356.html
https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/connecting-to-jira-for-user-management-960155582.html
fields.summary: Remove 'JIRA settings' link or provide an information page

fields.description:
Fisheye/Crucible uses gwt-rpc for admin POST calls.

Since, OWASP does not allow gwt-rpc, to achieve compliance with the OWASP default ruleset this should be replaced, or mitigated. (Rule #920420)
fields.summary: Replace gwt-rpc calls as they are not allowed by the OWASP 3.0 ruleset

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

On startup, Fisheye/Crucible 4.7.1 connected to a SQLServer database using Kerberos, produces the following error:
{noformat}
2019-07-24 08:49:55,109 ERROR [ThreadPoolAsyncTaskExecutor::Thread 1 ] fisheye DefaultDBControl-<init> - Unable to connect to SQLServer 2012 or newer database jdbc:sqlserver://xxxxxxxxx;databaseName=xxxxxx;integratedSecurity=true;authenticationScheme=JavaKerberos: com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerException: Kerberos Login failed: Integrated authentication failed. ClientConnectionId:xxxxxxxxxx due to javax.security.auth.login.LoginException (unable to find LoginModule class: com.sun.security.auth.module.Krb5LoginModule not found from bundle [com.atlassian.troubleshooting.plugin-fecru])
com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerException: Kerberos Login failed: Integrated authentication failed. ClientConnectionId:xxxxxxx due to javax.security.auth.login.LoginException (unable to find LoginModule class: com.sun.security.auth.module.Krb5LoginModule not found from bundle [com.atlassian.troubleshooting.plugin-fecru])
{noformat}
h3. Environment
 * Fisheye/Crucible 4.7.1 (new SQLServer drivers)
 * SQLServer (connected with jdbc )
 * Kerberos authentication enabled

Problem exists, because ATST plugin also connects to database during initialization. Plugins are managed by OSGi, so they are managed by different class loader. Unfortunately this class loader cannot load required class and thus ATST fails to initialize.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Connect Fisheye Crucible 4.7.1 to SQLServer DB (2014+) using Kerberos auth
 # Start Fisheye/Crucible

h3. Expected Results

Startup without errors logged.
h3. Actual Results

Error in logs during startup.
 The below exception is thrown in the xxxxxxx.log file:
{noformat}
xxxxxx ERROR [ThreadPoolAsyncTaskExecutor::Thread 1 ] fisheye DefaultDBControl-<init> - Unable to connect to SQLServer 2012 or newer database jdbc:sqlserver://xxxxxxxxx;databaseName=xxxxxx;integratedSecurity=true;authenticationScheme=JavaKerberos: com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerException: Kerberos Login failed: Integrated authentication failed. ClientConnectionId:xxxxxxxxxx due to javax.security.auth.login.LoginException (unable to find LoginModule class: com.sun.security.auth.module.Krb5LoginModule not found from bundle [com.atlassian.troubleshooting.plugin-fecru])
com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerException: Kerberos Login failed: Integrated authentication failed. ClientConnectionId:xxxxxxx due to javax.security.auth.login.LoginException (unable to find LoginModule class: com.sun.security.auth.module.Krb5LoginModule not found from bundle [com.atlassian.troubleshooting.plugin-fecru])
{noformat}
 
h3. Notes

Despite error, the database connects, and ATST plugin seems to work as far as creating support zips, as long as it is updated to latest version.

h3. Workaround

 Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Using Kerberos authentication with SQLServer produces errors for plugins connecting to the database

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

In [FishEye SSL configuration|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/fisheye-ssl-configuration-960155669.html] there is a recommendation/warning to create the keystore with Java 10. This should be removed, as Fisheye/Crucible only supports Java 8. During installation, we already point $JAVA_HOME to a supported java version.

The default keystore type for Java 10 is PKCS12 which creates issues for securing Fisheye/Crucible with SSL. Default for Java 8 is jks which works and has been tested.
h4. Suggested resolution

Remove the statement "The keystore must be created with Java 10 or later." from the documentation.

Add statement "We recommend that the keystore type is jks"
h3. Workaround

If the keystore is of type pkcs12 - convert the keystore to jks
fields.summary: Recommendation that the keystore must be created with Java 10 or later needs to be removed

nested exception is org.hibernate.PropertyValueException: not-null property references a null or transient value: com.cenqua.crucible.model.Project.permissionScheme; nested exception is org.springframework.beans.factory.BeanCreationException: Error creating bean with name 'projectManager': Invocation of init method failed; nested exception is org.hibernate.PropertyValueException: not-null property references a null or transient value: com.cenqua.crucible.model.Project.permissionScheme
{noformat}

h3. Expected Results

n/a

h3. Actual Results

Fisheye is unable to start due to Spring bean initialisation error. The below exception is thrown in the log file:

{noformat}
org.hibernate.PropertyValueException: not-null property references a null or transient value: com.cenqua.crucible.model.Project.permissionScheme
{noformat}

h3. Notes

This is caused by an inconsistent database state. Fisheye/Crucible expects a permission scheme, which is normally being created during setup. Because of the fact that backup import failed in the middle, this data is missing in the database.

h3. Workaround

Use an empty database to restore from the backup.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
When [{{git cherry-pick}}|https://git-scm.com/docs/git-cherry-pick] is used, the activity stream might list activity in wrong order, e.g., showing a file being added as the latest activity and the same file being changed as the older activity. Files cannot be changed before having been added first.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create, add, and commit a file
# Modify that file
# Use {{git cherry-pick}} to apply the change introduced
# Let Fisheye index these changesets
# Refresh the activity stream
# Note that in some cases, the activity shown is out of order:
!image-2019-06-13-10-49-58-230.png|thumbnail! 
For the bottom two pairs, the file added and file changed are in the correct git order, but the top 1 is reversed.

h3. Expected Results
It is possible to determine when a file is added and when a file is changed, so the activity stream should always show activity in the correct order regardless if git cherry-pick is used.

h3. Actual Results
Fisheye at first compares timestamps and when their values are the same than it compares the commit hashes. Due to that Fisheye will show wrong order when two commits have the same timestamps and first created commit has hash e.g "e123b54" and one created after has hash e.g. "a321b54".

The problem will occur always when one use cherry-pick as cherry-pick copy the commit date.

Each item in the pair appears sorted alphabetically descending, where higher number appear above lower numbers and letters appear above numbers.

h3. Workaround
Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available.
fields.summary: Activity stream out of order when git cherry-pick is used and timestamps are the same

fields.description:
Currently it's necessary to mention a project key in a smart commit review command if you have more than one project or a repo is not a project's default repo.

It would improve our workflow if we did not have to specify the crucible project associated with a repo and the smart commit command was able to deduce the correct project based on it being in the project content for a project.

The reason this would be beneficial is that we have many projects and repositories and our developers don't always know the project associated with a repo.
fields.summary: Enable smart commit review commands without project key for any repo associated with a project

fields.description:
*Edit*: I managed to reproduce this and have rephrased the title to denote the root cause:

When indexing the repo provided, the revision from the closed head is indexed as the ancestor for the file, while it's not really in it's ancestry. This causes the issue reported.

*Original description follows*:

When creating a review using the Branch Review feature for a Mercurial repository, if there is a grafted commit, it can cause the incorrect diff to be generated.

*Steps to reproduce*

Use the attached [^crc-8134.zip] repository and create a Branch Review for the {{feature}} branch with {{default}} as the base. The branch review will show the correct commits are being included:

!Screen Shot 2015-04-06 at 12.40.50 PM.png|thumbnail!

But the review that is created is incorrect:

!Screen Shot 2015-04-06 at 1.41.25 PM.png|thumbnail!

The review shows that the diff was created between {{00656ac}} and {{6a9681e}}. {{00656ac}} is the commit that was grafted from a closed branch.

Repository was created using the following steps:

# Commit to the {{default}} branch
# Create a {{feature}} branch from {{default}}
# Close the {{default}} branch
# Commit to the feature branch
# Graft a commit from the closed default branch to the feature branch
# Create a new {{default}} branch from a commit before the commit used in the graft above
# Merge the {{default}} branch into {{feature}}

*Expected results*

Branch review should not include the commit from the base branch and display the following diff. The following diff is expected:

{code:title=hg diff -r default:feature}diff -r 1c8ba5473fe2 -r 6a9681ed2688 branch.txt
--- /dev/null	Thu Jan 01 00:00:00 1970 +0000
+++ b/branch.txt	Mon Apr 06 12:34:13 2015 -0500
@@ -0,0 +1,1 @@
+First commit on feature branch
\ No newline at end of file
diff -r 1c8ba5473fe2 -r 6a9681ed2688 important.txt
--- a/important.txt	Mon Apr 06 12:32:34 2015 -0500
+++ b/important.txt	Mon Apr 06 12:34:13 2015 -0500
@@ -1,2 +1,4 @@
 First commit on default
-Second commit on default
\ No newline at end of file
+Second commit on default
+Third commit on default
+Fourth commit on feature branch
\ No newline at end of file{code}

*Workaround*

Use the Browse Changesets option when creating the review and manually select the commits on the branch.
fields.summary: Revisions from closed heads are considered ancestors for files

fields.description:
h4. Problem
Support for AJP has ended in Fisheye since version 4.0, nevertheless it could still work. With Fisheye 4.7 and the upgrade of the Jetty Server to 9.4 using ajp is not only deprecated/unsupported but does not work. 

Nevertheless, the option to use an AJP bind address is still present in the Fisheye UI, which is redundant and can be confusing.

h4. Solution
Remove the option from *Global Settings* > *Server*
fields.summary: Remove unsupported ajp13 bind option from Fisheye server settings

fields.description:
*Problem description*
As part of fixing  a security vulnerability  [FE\-7163: Stored XSS in administrative linker functionality through the href parameter \- CVE\-2018\-20240 (fixed in FishEye 4.7.0)|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/FE-7163] we introduce the file <FISHEYE_HOME>/syntax/url.def to whitelist url definitions. As consequence, some non-http linkers without entry in that file, stopped working in Fisheye/Crucible v 4.7

*Suggestion* 
Add more definitions as we encounter more use cases, such as a definition for *advcrm*

*Workaround*
For *advcrm* add the following entry in the file <FISHEYE_HOME>/syntax/url.def

{noformat}
# advcrm
  /\b(?:advcrm:(?:(?:[a-zA-Z\d$\-_.+!*'(),;\/?:@&=]|(?:%[a-fA-F\d]{2}))+))/ : {
    region {href="${0}";}
  }{noformat}
Thanks to that, all links with this scheme (and rest of the url will pass this regex check) will be rendered on UI.

Steps:
 # Switch off Fisheye/Crucible
 # add new entry to the file (file location and entry above)
 # launch Fisheye/Crucible
 # All links should be rendered
fields.summary: Add whitelist entry for non-HTTP linker advcrm
Add "location" parameter to /rest-service-fecru/admin/repositories

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

You are able to have Permissions Schemes with spaces in the UI but when using the REST API it is rejected
h3. Steps to Reproduce

 # Create a permissions scheme with /rest-service-fecru/admin/permission-schemes with space in it. Escaped or not,

h3. Expected Results

The permissions scheme is created

h3. Actual Results

Fails with:
{noformat}
{
    "code": "IllegalArgument",
    "message": "Invalid permission key name, only alphanumeric values are allowed: ([A-Za-z0-9\\-]+)"
}
{noformat}
h3. Notes

This is possible to do in the UI without issue.

h3. Workaround

Use the UI or run the following curl command that imitates the UI call:

{code}
curl -s -u username:password \
-XPOST \
-H'X-Atlassian-Token:no-check' \
-H'Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded' \
-H'Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml' \
-d "name=Name+with+plus+instead+of+space" \
<FISHEYE URL>/admin/newPermScheme.do
{code}
fields.summary: Running Permission Scheme API doesn't align with UI functionality

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="ISO-8859-1"?>

                </Call>
        </Get>
</Configure>
{code} 
# Restart Fisheye.
fields.summary: Fisheye/Crucible 4.7+ unable to add additional HTTP connector

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When setting java parameters using the {{FISHEYE_INST/system.properties}} method as per the [JVM system properties|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye045/administering-fisheye/system-settings/jvm-system-properties#JVMsystemproperties-Fisheyepipelineindexing], Fisheye does not recognize any of the java parameters after restarting the application.
h3. Environment
 * N/A

h3. Steps to Reproduce

Set any java parameter on the *system.properties* file located in the Fisheye data directory.

N/A
h3. Expected Results

After restarting the application, the parameters should be shown in the on the {{Administration > System Info page.}}
h3. Actual Results

The parameters set in *system.properties* are not grabbed by the application, and the parameters are not shown in the {{{Administration > System Info page.}}
h3. Workaround

Set the JVM parameters via Environment Variable.
fields.summary: system.properties not working

fields.description:
TLS version 1.0 and 1.1 are considered not secure enough and are being deprecated on various platforms, such as GMail or Office365. 

Fisheye should use the latest version of TLS protocol by default.

 

Microsoft announcement: "We're retiring 3DES in Office 365 beginning February 28, 2019" - it requires change from TLS 1.0 to 1.2.

 
h3. Workaround

Configure TLS version using system properties.
h4. StartTLS with TLSv1.2

Decompiled bytecode from com.sun.mail.util.SocketFetcher#startTLS shows that list of protocols is hard-coded:
{code:java}
/*
 * At least the UW IMAP server insists on only the TLSv1
 * protocol for STARTTLS, and won't accept the old SSLv2
 * or SSLv3 protocols.  Here we enable only the TLSv1
 * protocol.  XXX - this should probably be parameterized.
 */
((SSLSocket)socket).setEnabledProtocols(new String[] {"TLSv1"});
{code}
Therefore, it's not possible to configure it via system properties (like it's possible for SMTPS). It also means that the mail library was probably never tested with newer TLS version. The only method to switch a protocol is to use Byteman, which can manipulate Java bytecode at runtime. {color:#ff0000}For these reasons we strongly recommend using SMTPS with TLSv1.2 (which is supported) instead of hacking the runtime.{color}

If you sill want to configure it with StartTLS, do the following.
 # Download the attached [^use-tls12.btm] script and save it on your Fisheye server.
 (!) This rule will swap TLSv1 with TLSv1.2 for *any* SSL socket connections. It may affect your plugins or repository connections.
 # Enable Byteman for Fisheye:
 (!) Do not follow the manual from [Enable Byteman for additional logging in Fisheye and Crucible|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fishkb/enable-byteman-for-additional-logging-in-fisheye-and-crucible-943956769.html] - the reason is that Byteman must be loaded by the bootstrap class loader as it has to modify a class from JRE.
 ** *In Linux:*
 1. Add the following environment variable:
{noformat}
export FISHEYE_OPTS="-javaagent:<full path to Fisheye installation directory>/tools/byteman/lib/byteman.jar=boot:<full path to Fisheye installation directory>/tools/byteman/lib/byteman.jar,listener:true,script:<full path to the>/use-tls12.btm"
{noformat}
Replacing the path placeholders accordingly.
 2. Restart Fisheye
 ** *In Windows and started manually* (by running {{<Fisheye installation directory>\bin\start.bat}} or {{<Fisheye installation directory>\bin\run.bat}}):
1. Create or update the {{FISHEYE_OPTS}} Windows Environment Variable, making sure it has at least the following (as there may be other settings already in place):
{noformat}
-javaagent:<full path to Fisheye installation directory>\tools\byteman\lib\byteman.jar=listener:true,script:<full path to the>\use-tls12.btm
{noformat}
Replacing the path placeholders accordingly.
 2. Restart Fisheye
 ** *In Windows and started as service:*
1. Go to {{<Fisheye installation directory>\bin}} and execute either {{service.bat manage}} or {{prunmgr.exe "//ES//<SERVICE_NAME>"}}, where {{<SERVICE_NAME>}} is the Windows Service name used by Fisheye.
 2. In the {{Atlassian Fisheye Properties}} window that will open, go to {{Java}} tab
 3. Add the following in a new line in {{Java Options}} field:
{noformat}
-javaagent:<Fisheye installation directory>\tools\byteman\lib\byteman.jar=boot:<Fisheye installation directory>\tools\byteman\lib\byteman.jar,listener:true,script:<full path to the>\use-tls12.btm
{noformat}
Replacing the path placeholders accordingly.
 4. Go to {{General}} tab, then stop and start the service
# After it's up and running, verify that rules have been loaded correctly.
** In Linux, run:
{noformat}
<Fisheye installation directory>/tools/byteman/list-rules.sh
{noformat}
** In Windows, run:
{noformat}
<Fisheye installation directory>/tools/byteman/list-rules.bat
{noformat}
# You should see the rule and a message like this:
{noformat}
Transformed in:
loader: sun.misc.Launcher$AppClassLoader@18b4aac2
trigger method: sun.security.ssl.SSLSocketImpl.setEnabledProtocols(java.lang.String[]) void
{noformat}
# Configure mail settings in "Administration > Server > Mail Server > Edit config"
 ** Set "Use SSL/TLS" to {{true}}.
 ** Put host name, port, username, password.

h4. SMTPS with TLSv1.2

Please read the workaround described in FE-3912.
fields.summary: Fisheye mail should use TLSv1.2 instead of TLSv1 or TLSv1.1

fields.description:
In the Repository Defaults page, it is possible to give users Read and Admin on repos by default but it is not possible to restrict access by default.
This would be useful, as we want all logged in users to have access to repos by default, except for a few contractors.

I would imagine this would just be in the form of an additional drop down option in the permissions defaults page.
fields.summary: Allow restricting access to user or group by default
Support Git 2.21

fields.description: The DiskFileItem class from the Apache Commons FileUpload library before version 1.3.3 was vulnerable to CVE-2016-1000031.  Atlassian Fisheye was using a vulnerable version of this library, although not the DiskFileItem class.  Fisheye has been updated to use the safe version of the Apache Commons FileUpload library.
fields.summary: Fisheye had a vulnerable version of Apache Commons FileUpload - CVE-2016-1000031

fields.description: The administrative linker functionality in Atlassian Fisheye before version 4.7.0 allows remote attackers to inject arbitrary HTML or JavaScript via a cross site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in the href parameter.
fields.summary: Stored XSS in administrative linker functionality through the href parameter - CVE-2018-20240

fields.description: The Edit upload resource for a review in Atlassian Fisheye before version 4.7.0 allows remote attackers to inject arbitrary HTML or JavaScript via a cross site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in the wbuser parameter.
fields.summary: XSS in edit upload for a review through the wbuser parameter - CVE-2018-20241

fields.description: The version of the Application Links plugin used in Fisheye before version 4.7.0 allows remote attackers to inject arbitrary HTML or JavaScript via a cross site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in the applinkStartingUrl parameter. See https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/APL-1373 for more details.
fields.summary: XSS in the listApplicationLinks resource of the Application links plugin - CVE-2018-20239

fields.description: JRE version was updated from 1.8.0_102 to *1.8.0_192*
fields.summary: Update JRE version bundled in Windows installer
Deprecate 32-bit windows installer

fields.description:
In JIRA 8 the Lucene engine responsible for indexing has been upgraded from version 3.3 to version 7.6. As a result of this action (and data restructuring) they gained 48% reduction of Lucene index size and significant improvements in indexing speed and search. See [introducing-jira-software-8-0|https://www.atlassian.com/blog/jira-software/introducing-jira-software-8-0] for details

Let's do the same for Fisheye.
fields.summary: Upgrade Lucene library to 7.6 or newer to reduce index size and improve indexing speed

fields.description: 4.9rc0 is available already https://www.mercurial-scm.org/repo/hg/rev/593718ff5844
fields.summary: Support Mercurial 4.9

fields.description:
From EcmaScript 2015:

 * [Array static methods|http://kangax.github.io/compat-table/es6/#test-Array_static_methods] (e.g., {{Array.from}})

 * [Array prototype methods|http://kangax.github.io/compat-table/es6/#test-Array.prototype_methods] (e.g., {{[].find}}, {{[].keys}}, {{[].values}}, {{[].entries}})

 * [Object static methods|http://kangax.github.io/compat-table/es6/#test-Object_static_methods] (e.g., {{Object.assign}})

 * [Promise|http://kangax.github.io/compat-table/es6/#test-Promise]

 * [String static methods|http://kangax.github.io/compat-table/es6/#test-String_static_methods]

 * [String prototype methods|http://kangax.github.io/compat-table/es6/#test-String.prototype_methods]

 From EcmaScript 2016:

 * [Array prototype methods|http://kangax.github.io/compat-table/es2016plus/#test-Array.prototype.includes] (e.g., {{[].includes}})

 From WhatWG

 * [window.fetch|https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/API/Fetch_API]
fields.summary: Front-end runtime polyfills for a subset of EcmaScript 2015 features

fields.description:
Currently content linker (in comments, description etc) supports schemes: http(s)://, ftp://, nntp:, news:, telnet:, mailto:, file://.

It shall support more schemes, such as: 

ftps://
skype:
callto:
facetime:
git:
irc:
irc6:
feed:
cvs:
svn:
mvn:
ssh:
scp://
sftp://
itms:
notes:
hipchat://
sourcetree:
urn:
tel:
xmpp:
vnc:
rdp:
whatsapp:
slack:
sip:
sips:
magnet:
fields.summary: Support more URI schemes in content linker

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Jira used to be more relaxed and allow the underscore character to be present in Jira project keys, which has since been removed. Fisheye/Crucible still support the old standard. This update would allow Fisheye/Crucible to match Jira's documentation and would match the current Jira standard for issue keys.

h3. [Jira's current Standard|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirasoftwareserver0711/referencing-issues-in-your-development-work-955166285.html]:
"The default Jira key format – that is, two or more uppercase letters ([A-Z][A-Z]+), followed by a hyphen and the issue number."

h3. Current Behavior
If a Jira issue key is placed in a review's title, the below will occur:
"Title to Crucible review_ABC-123"
Actual Jira issue key: ABC-123
What Crucible will parse and think is the issue key: review_ABC-123
fields.summary: Update Jira Issue project key formats to reflect Jira's more restrictive default

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Fisheye treating the *.doc* and *.xslx* MIME type as binary. As for the *.xslx*, this was added in the {{FISHEYE_INST/raw-mime.types}} file but the changes were not applied.

h3. Environment
* Fisheye Crucible version 4.6.1
* File type Excel - .xslx and Document - .doc

h3. Steps to Reproduce
h5. Document file type
# Add a file called _sample.doc_ in the SVN repository.
# View the _sample.doc_  in the Fisheye UI's repository _Source_. 

h5. Excel file type
# Stop the Fisheye.
# Edit the {{FISHEYE_INST/raw-mime.types}} to have the following:
{code:java}
text/xml			xml xsl xlsx
{code}
# Restart the Fisheye
# Add a file called _sample.doc_ in the SVN repository.
# View the _sample.doc_  in the Fisheye UI's repository _Source_. 

h3. Expected Results
View the file content

h3. Actual Results
Fisheye showing the file as binary. The file is only available to download.

h3. Workaround
Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Fisheye does not show content for MIME type doc and xslx

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
[Permissions|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/permissions-960155528.html] information on a repository persist in {{cru_repo_group_perm}} table even when the repository is deleted via [Managing your repositories|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/managing-your-repositories-960155450.html]. 

h3. Suggested Solution
Record in {{cru_repo_group_perm}} table should be removed once the linked repository is deleted. 

h3. Why this is important
 
The table {{cru_repo_group_perm}} uses repository name as a key. Therefore, if a same name as a repository that has been previously deleted is named, the old permission would be applied for the new one again.
fields.summary: Permission information persists in DB even when repository deleted

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
In certain corporate security policies, it's required to prevent the application server from sending its version in the HTTP headers.

h3. Suggested Solution
Implement configurable system property allowing to set the adjustable boolean value for [setSendServerVersion Jetty property|https://www.eclipse.org/jetty/javadoc/current/org/eclipse/jetty/server/HttpConfiguration.html#setSendServerVersion-boolean-]
 
h3. Workaround 
The version of the application server can be hidden behind the [reverse proxy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/configuring-the-fisheye-web-server-960155665.html] located on the same host as Fisheye.
fields.summary: Provide the configurable option to hide the application server version

fields.description:
By default, Fisheye truncates changesets that breach 10000 path changes. This can cause indexes not being complete so files may not appear or may not be searchable. It would be helpful to have some form of banner or warning for a repository if it has hit that limit so that admins can take action.


h3. Workaround

Open 'Administration' > 'Troubleshooting and support' > 'Log analyzer' tab. If the log analyser finds a log line like:

{noformat}Changeset ...: indexed paths truncated at 10000{noformat}

it will show it in a report and link to the KB article:

https://confluence.atlassian.com/fishkb/indexed-paths-truncated-at-10000-320602645.html

 !log-analyser.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Notify users when index may not be complete.

fields.description:
The current EyeQL 'on branch' clause search commits that are committed on the branch only:
{noformat} select revisions from dir "/" where (on branch testbranch and comment matches "commit on testbranch") order by date desc group by changeset return path, revision, author, date, csid 
{noformat}
The above EyeQL return the changesets that are committed on testbranch.

After testbranch is merged into master branch, the search for the same commits on master branch does not work:
{noformat} select revisions from dir "/" where (on branch master and comment matches "commit on testbranch") order by date desc group by changeset return path, revision, author, date, csid
{noformat}
The above EyeQL does not return any result. 

We need EyeQL to perform search for the changesets (committed on the branch or merged into the branch) when using 'on branch' clause
fields.summary: EyeQL 'on branch' clause returns incorrect results

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
As can be seen at [Email Notifications Not Being Sent|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fishkb/email-notifications-not-being-sent-691013114.html], email notifications might stop being sent and this is concerning because Fisheye admins have no way of knowing they are in a problem state, unless end users report it. Users use watches in order to keep abreast of changes they otherwise may not know about - so they won't know that watches aren't working unless they happen to discover a change that they weren't notified about through the watch.

Currently the only way of discovering that there are pending emails is by *manually* running the SQL query from the article from time to time.

h3. Suggested Solution
Fisheye should have a recurring job that runs the SQL query outlined in that article *automatically* and alerts Fisheye admins someway (not via email, of course) whenever pending emails exist for a given period of time.

h3. Workaround
There are currently no workarounds in order to automate that.
fields.summary: Add a job for tracking pending email notifications

fields.summary: Migrate BoneCP to HikariCP

fields.description:
h3. Symptoms

In case when a database connection is terminated (possibly due to network error) before a tracked statement is closed, the database connection may not be returned to the BoneCP pool, resulting in a connection leak. This probably occurs at heavier database load as normally statements finish before the connection is closed.

A stack trace when hibernate connection fails to release because physical connection is already terminated:

{noformat}
Caused by: java.sql.SQLRecoverableException: Closed Connection
at oracle.jdbc.driver.PhysicalConnection.needLine(PhysicalConnection.java:3247) [ojdbc8-12.2.0.1.jar:12.2.0.1.0]
...
at com.jolbox.bonecp.StatementHandle.closeStatement(StatementHandle.java:151) [bonecp-0.7.1.RELEASE.jar:0.7.1.RELEASE]
at com.jolbox.bonecp.StatementHandle.close(StatementHandle.java:185) [bonecp-0.7.1.RELEASE.jar:0.7.1.RELEASE]
...
at com.cenqua.crucible.hibernate.trackingstatements.TrackingStatementsConnection.closeTrackedStatements(TrackingStatementsConnection.java:52) [fisheye.jar:?]
at com.cenqua.crucible.hibernate.trackingstatements.TrackingStatementsConnection.close(TrackingStatementsConnection.java:88) [fisheye.jar:?]
at com.cenqua.crucible.hibernate.trackingstatements.TrackingStatementsConnectionProvider.closeConnection(TrackingStatementsConnectionProvider.java:34) [fisheye.jar:?]
at org.hibernate.internal.AbstractSessionImpl$NonContextualJdbcConnectionAccess.releaseConnection(AbstractSessionImpl.java:312) [hibernate-core-4.2.13.Final.jar:4.2.13.Final]
at org.hibernate.engine.jdbc.internal.LogicalConnectionImpl.releaseConnection(LogicalConnectionImpl.java:241) [hibernate-core-4.2.13.Final.jar:4.2.13.Final]
{noformat}

A typical web thread waiting for a DB connection when all available connections are exhausted:

{noformat}
"qtp402207819-200" #200 prio=5 os_prio=31 tid=0x00007fb15dfcd000 nid=0x11e0f waiting on condition [0x0000700018785000]
java.lang.Thread.State: TIMED_WAITING (parking)
at sun.misc.Unsafe.park(Native Method)
- parking to wait for <0x00000007811d11a0> (a com.jolbox.bonecp.BoundedLinkedTransferQueue)
at java.util.concurrent.locks.LockSupport.parkNanos(LockSupport.java:215)
at jsr166y.LinkedTransferQueue.awaitMatch(LinkedTransferQueue.java:691)
at jsr166y.LinkedTransferQueue.xfer(LinkedTransferQueue.java:600)
at jsr166y.LinkedTransferQueue.poll(LinkedTransferQueue.java:1068)
at com.jolbox.bonecp.BoundedLinkedTransferQueue.poll(BoundedLinkedTransferQueue.java:78)
at com.jolbox.bonecp.BoneCP.getConnection(BoneCP.java:500) <<<<<<<<<
at com.cenqua.crucible.hibernate.trackingstatements.HibernateBonceCPConnectionProvider.getConnection(HibernateBonceCPConnectionProvider.java:171)
at com.cenqua.crucible.hibernate.trackingstatements.TrackingStatementsConnectionProvider.getConnection(TrackingStatementsConnectionProvider.java:26)
at org.hibernate.internal.AbstractSessionImpl$NonContextualJdbcConnectionAccess.obtainConnection(AbstractSessionImpl.java:301)
at org.hibernate.engine.jdbc.internal.LogicalConnectionImpl.obtainConnection(LogicalConnectionImpl.java:214)
at org.hibernate.engine.jdbc.internal.LogicalConnectionImpl.getConnection(LogicalConnectionImpl.java:157)
at org.hibernate.engine.transaction.internal.jdbc.JdbcTransaction.doBegin(JdbcTransaction.java:67)
{noformat}

Application becomes unresponsive as web threads (qtp-*) are hanging on BoneCP.getConnection.

h3. Steps to reproduce

T.B.D.

h3. Workaround

Restart Fisheye server.

h3. Related issues
 * FE-7123 upgrade to BoneCP 0.8.0, which contains several bug fixes for leaking connections
 * FE-7127 migration to HikariCP, a successor of BoneCP
 * CRUC-7083 a fix delivered for non-closed statements in 3.8.0
fields.summary: Database connections are not returned to the BoneCP pool when a physical connection is broken

fields.description:
Hi,

a customer of our addon reported a bug that is caused by an old version of Xerces used in Fecru. 
This Xerces bug was already fixed in 2005 with version 2.8.0: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/XERCESJ-1106.
The currently supported versions of Fecru make use of the older Xerces version 2.7.1. 

Some background: we are using opensaml3 to handle SAML requests and responses. A common security method in SAML is, that a responses or parts of the response are signed. The signature is sent inline in the XML body of the SAML response. The validation of such a signature by opensaml3 results in a ClassCastException (see attached screenshot). 
We were not able to build a workaround that does not require to modify the Fecru instance or to remove functionality by our addon (that possible could have security implications for the customer).

In our tests, we were able to solve this issue by updating the Xerces lib to at least version 2.8.0 in the lib folder of Xerces. But, of course, you will understand that we cannot give any guarantee that this does not affect other parts of Fecru. Also it wouldn't be a good user experience to expect a customer to update a system library to get an addon running.

That means that we are currently not able to provide the expected functionality for many customers in the default setup of our addon.

Could you please advise how we should proceed with the issue?

Best regards,
Oliver
fields.summary: ClassCastException due to validation of SAML assertion signature

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

We provide some information regarding the use of SSH agents for Unix style systems and Windows but it defaults to the usage of OpenSSH and does not define potential steps for a customer to take if they do not use OpenSSH on their system such as Centrify.

h3. Suggested Solution

Add additions to the *{{Notes}}* section of the [Fisheye Authentication|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/authentication-298976915.html] page that includes how SSH works and workaround java arguments.  Below is a primer:

----

h5. How SSH works in Fisheye

Fisheye does not bundle any SSH clients and instead relies on what is available in your server infrastructure. For Unix-based systems, this is typically in the form of OpenSSH. When Fisheye attempts to connect to a repository, such as through a Bitbucket Server application link, it uses SSH to do so. Below are the steps that occur to identify and execute an SSH connection:

# The connection is initiated to connect with repository via SSH
# Fisheye checks to see if *{{SSH_EXEC}}* environment variable is set on the server. 
# If *{{SSH_EXEC}}* is NOT set then it checks to see if the JVM argument *{{-Dssh.exe}}* is set.
# If JVM argument *{{-Dssh.exe}}* is NOT set, it searches for SSH/SSH.exe on PATH. 
# If SSH is found on the PATH, then it resolves the _canonical_ path for SSH.
# Fisheye then sets *{{SSH_EXEC}}* environment variable with the canonical path it just resolved.

h5. Using Centrify SSH

As noted, OpenSSH is in the default library used for SSH on Unix based systems. (For Windows, see below “SSH connectivity tools under Windows") 

To run Fisheye with Centrify SSH, you will likely need to set the JVM argument *{{-Dssh.exe}}* to the path for SSH:
# Set environment variable *{{FISHEYE_OPTS}}* with value
{code:borderStyle=solid}
-Dssh.exe=/path/to/ssh 
{code}
# Restart the application
# Navigate to *{{Administration > Sys Info/Support > System Info}}* and check the output under *{{JVM Input Arguments}}* to verify the argument has been set.

(!) There is a known issue with running Centrify OpenSSH commands. Please review the [Centrify KB article|https://centrify.force.com/support/Article/KB-8165-Running-Centrify-OpenSSH-Commands-an-Error-is-Thrown-ld-so-1-ssh-fatal-relocation-error/] on how to deal with the execution of Centrify SSH.
fields.summary: Improve Fisheye Authentication documentation for additional SSH client options and how SSH works

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Whenever a file with a {{utf8}} Perforce filetype containing a BOM header is submitted to depot, Fisheye shows this file as binary. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Submit a file with {{utf8}} Perforce filetype containing a BOM header to the depot
# Wait until this file is indexed
# Try to open this file in repository browser
# Fisheye will say that the file is binary

h3. Expected Results
Fisheye should show the file source

h3. Actual Results
Fisheye is saying that the file is binary, offering the option to download it.

h3. Perforce versions 
# 2015.2
# 2016.2

h3.Workarounds
* Change the Perforce filetype to {{text}} with removing BOM header
fields.summary: Perforce: Submitted UTF-8 file with BOM header shows up as binary in repository browser
